number of helpful: 427 of 445 people (96%) found this review helpful43 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												As the title indicates, LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga is an amalgamation of two earlier games, LEGO Star Wars: The Video Game and Lego Star Wars II: The Original Saga.  I'm calling this an amalgamation as opposed to a compilation due to the fact that the gameplay is presented as a single uninterrupted experience, rather than as two that are separate and distinct.  Traveler's Tales has also added some additional content that was not present in either of the earlier stand-alone games.  LEGO Star Wars: The Video Game was the very first LEGO game developed by Traveler's Tales (henceforth referred to as TT), whereas the Original Saga was the second title they developed under the LEGO banner.  These titles form the foundation of what are now familiar gameplay features found in nearly all subsequently developed LEGO games.  The hallmark sense of humor is here (although like all of the earlier TT LEGO games, there is no spoken dialog), as are the simple LEGO building puzzle elements.  We find a familiar hub based level structure with each level branching from that central hub, and of course the LEGO collect-a-thon aspects make their debut here including the requisite stud collection, mini-kits, red bricks, golden bricks, etc.  So while a majority of the gameplay elements will be familiar to those who have previously dabbled in LEGO games, it's interesting nonetheless see the ways in which TT was still experimenting with their formula, solidifying what would become their trademark style.  This last bit is particularly interesting in the context of The Complete Saga, because you can see Traveler's Tales incorporating lessons learned and improving their games between the separate bookends of the Prequel Levels (featured in LEGO Star Wars: The Video Game), and the original trilogy levels (as featured in The Original Saga).  From a historical standpoint it's striking to see how quickly Traveler's Tales was able to deftly incorporate lessons learned from the first game and use them to improve the second game.  From a gameplay standpoint though, this creates a bit of dissonance.  Stylistically, the Original Saga is a much more robust game.  The levels are longer and more complex, the puzzles are generally more interesting, the graphical elements are improved upon, etc.  So while the levels in Complete Saga are presented seamlessly, in practice you will notice a very definitive division between the older (prequel) levels and the newer (original saga) levels.  Speaking as a bit of a Star Wars nerd I'm happy that the Original Saga levels are the ones with better gameplay.As I mentioned before, the gameplay elements here will be very familiar to anyone who has played TT LEGO games before.  Given the ubiquitous nature of these games, you probably already know whether this game is for you.  If you love the LEGO formula you'll find a lot to love here.  If the 'break everything in sight collect-a-thon' turns you off, well … these aren't the droids you're looking for.  <groan>  As I mentioned earlier, TT was still developing their trademark style in these games, so even those who have enjoyed more recent LEGO titles might find some of the elements featured here to be a bit rudimentary.  The controls are (naturally) very familiar, but at the same time feel slightly 'looser' than later LEGO titles.  Switching between characters can be a bit tedious since TT had yet to develop the character wheel system seen in more recent titles.  This means that you need to stand directly next to the character you wish to switch to, and since you often have several characters crowding in on you this can lead to several instances of switching to the wrong character.  This can be slightly rage inducing when you're under attack.  Speaking of computer controlled characters, they are basically useless while not under your direct control, and even worse you may find many circumstances in which they will actively become a hindrance.  There were several circumstances in which I would need to destroy one of my computer controlled allies simply to create a clear line of fire.  Get the heck out of the way Chewie!  And while I'm on this topic, I won't lie, sometimes I would randomly just lay a beat down on Jar-Jar, because … Jar-Jar.I need to make special mention of the collectible elements in this game, because that aspect has really been dialed to eleven.  If you're like me and you like to unlock everything these games have to offer, well … you're going to be here a while.  You'll need to play through every level no less than four times.  You'll play a level once in story mode which will unlock free play mode.  Then you'll need to play through free play mode to clean up any of the standard remaining goals in that level.  Once you've completely finished the episode you'll unlock Challenge and Super Story modes.  So you'll play each level again in Challenge mode to retrieve the blue mini-kits, and lastly you'll play through them yet again in Super Story mode which is a time-based score attack and simply adds to your completion percentage.  Four times for every level.  Once you couple this with the fact that this game features unskippable cut scenes, it can all start to become a bit … tedious.  As I mentioned, this part really only applies to completionists, so your mileage may vary significantly in this regard.  I think this is another area in which TT was still figuring out the formula, which in this case meant finding an acceptable line between "collect a bunch of unlockables" and "OMFG, will it ever end!?"The story is … well, if you don't know it by now, you should schedule yourself for a Star Wars movie marathon, stat.  Having said that, you don't need to be a Star Wars scholar to appreciate the game for what it is.  In point of fact it can be a great introduction to the Star Wars universe for young padawan Star Wars fans looking to get a toehold on the series.  It keeps everything fairly light and deftly negotiates some of the darker aspects of the story.  It's also a great game to play co-op with young ones.  The game treats its subject matter with great reverence and humor.  As a Star Wars fan I enjoyed the game from beginning to end, and this game easily fits within the upper echelons of the greatest Start Wars games ever released.  There are six levels devoted to each movie within the Star Wars saga, and among them you will find all the standard Star Wars set pieces you might expect in a game of this nature along with some surprising gems.  The levels feature a mix of on-foot and piloted air/space craft missions.  All the missions are paced very well, and keep things moving along at a nice clip.  Furthermore the plethora of unlockable characters available keeps things fresh enough so that repeated playthroughs seldom feel stale.Overall the games presented here are highly enjoyable and well done.  Even in their first forays into LEGO games, TT was already onto a winning formula that would continue to be refined in later games.  This game gets my recommendation for fans of simple puzzle-based action adventure games appropriate for gamers both young and old, and especially for being a great co-op game.

												When the first LEGO Star Wars game came out in 2005 my dad bought me a PS2 and the game. My 6 year old self was extremely happy that my favorite toy and my all time favorite movie series were packed into a well made video game! When the second game was released the next year, I asked my dad to get it for me and we went to Gamestop and bought it. My dad lives out of the country now so I don't get to see him much but these games really brought my dad and I together and playing them now gives me the feels :P. I highly recommend this game for anyone who loves LEGO, Star Wars, or just wants a great game to pass the time with until Half Life 3 comes out!

One of the Best LEGO Games!This game has to be my favourite LEGO game out there. It is nostalgic playing through it again and is once again a great experience. You get to play through the whole Star Wars movie story from start to finish. There is great replayability as throughout the game you unlock various characters in which you can use in any level you have beaten in free mode. The graphics are great and what you'd expect from a LEGO game and it runs smoothly too. The combat is fun especially with each character having its unique abilities. The puzzles occasionally make you think but they aren't too challenging.Whether or not you are a Star Wars fan if you like LEGO games this is one that is a must buy!

number of helpful: 37 of 37 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												In my opinion, this LEGO game is one of the best ones I have ever played, and I've played almost every single LEGO game. Here's why I enjoyed it so much.First off, replay value. I have beaten this game twice on a Nintendo Wii I had, and now once here on PC. Since there are so many levels, collectables, funny cutscenes, and it staying very true to all six Star Wars movies, it really never gets old.Which brings me to my second point. This game lasts for quite some time, especially if you are in it to collect everything. You'll have to play through every level (36 levels) about 2 or 3 times to get everything. Sounds tedious, right? Well, no. You see, once you have done story mode, like all other LEGO games, you can go back with any other characters and power on through the level. It's very fun to go back and explore the places you can't get to in story mode.So now the third reason why this game is so fun. Throughout the game you can collect "Power Bricks" which enable you to do things like become invincible and make the in-game currency, the studs, worth many times their original value. This makes it so you can buy vehicles, characters, and other things faster. You can also make it so your Jedi Slam does more damage, disable enemy weapons, and so much more.And finally, the shear amount of characters is amazing. There are over 120 characters, some being different variations of the same person and lots of others. You can even be Indiana Jones! Being set in the Star Wars universe, it's only natural there would be plenty of characters to choose from, and this game doesn't disappoint.But what are the levels like? They are all unique, providing different things to do in every level. However, a few levels are a bit repetitve and boring. One or two are extremely hard in story mode, such as one where you have to fly around and destroy enemy ships and weapons. But the rest of the levels certainly make up for them.With this game having the replay value and normal LEGO humor, it's a fantastic game to play. I got halfway through the game about 17 hours in, so it's certainly not a short game, especially if you are a completionist like me and want to get to 100%. So if you have never played it and were wondering, I strongly recommend it! 9/10.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												LEGO Star Wars - The Complete Saga, takes the Original Trilogy of; A New Hope, The Empire Strikes Back, and Return of the Jedi, and combines it with; The Phantom Menace, The Clone Wars, and Revenge of the Sith. It was released in 2007.As is custom with LEGO games, you collect Gold Bricks to unlock additional content, collect coins to purchase things, and complete missions to further the story. A difference between the Complete Saga and the original  LEGO Star Wars: The Video Game, are two previously deleted levels, The Bounty Hunter's Pursuit, and Anakin's Flight. These are unlockable by obtaining Gold Bricks.As with many of the other LEGO games, Single Player Mode as well as Co-operative Two-Player mode is available locally. Having played this particular game on both the PS3, as well as PC, I can say I haven't seen any difference. If you enjoy the LEGO series, this is a must have for the collection. If you are new to LEGO games, LEGO Star Wars - The Complete Saga is a great place to start.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												So this is Lego Star Wars - The Complete Saga, it's the sequel to Lego Star Wars II, which was in turn a Sequel to Lego Star Wars. If you've played this as a kid on the Ps2 like I have, you know what you're getting into, but regardless here's a review.The Complete Saga features the 6 pre-force awakens episodes - the prequel era episodes through the original trilogy - and levels are based on scenes and events in the movies.So the game starts you off in the first level of Episode 1, the Phantom Menace, in the Trade Federation blockade ship Episode 1 largely started in. You play as Qui-Gon and Obi-Wan and try to escape from the ship, the first level serving as a tutorial on how the functions of the game work, such as the force, building, studs, minikits, deflecting blaster shots, and access panels only characters can access.After you finish that level, you're free to go to any of the other episodes of the Prequels/OT. Which is rather nice and actually really well thought out, while you can continue with the plot of TPM, you're allowed to jump to any of the other episodes and start off at level 1. You don't have to complete all the levels of TPM to move on to AOTC, for example. The game is really open and free, and as such comes off as a really good title.The gameplay is just what you would expect from a Lego game, it's fun, interactive, and runs great. Most props are composed of Legos in the game, with the exception of environments (Which still look good) and it gives the game and levels a great atmosphere that you expect from a Lego game.As you go through the game, you can unlock more things with money, be it custom characters, cheats, or hints from the store. And can use the characters when replaying missions.Meanwhile, the explanation of the story in the game is arguably better than how it's explained in some of the films. This being an early Lego game,(since modern Lego games seem to have dialogue) there is no dialogue and thus the cutscenes explaining the story have to rely on only visuals to get the plot across, and it's honestly genius how they explain some of the Episode Plots. The cutscenes for the Phantom Menace Episode, for example, are not only more funny than the actual film it's based on, but the game's explanations of the story in the episode in the cutscenes more easily explain the plot of the film, and you're able to get a gist of what's going on. Which, in the case of TPM, where the conflict is based on a trade blockade dispute,(and honestly one of the most difficult plots to explain due to how messy it is for a Star Wars film) is very important for game cutscenes to be short and to the point, and this game is great at explaining stuff by way of 15 second cutscenes.The game runs fantastically and I've yet to find a PC of mine that cannot run it, it's greatly optimized and allows for great customization of settings, including the controls. Though the mouse cannot be bound as a key, which confused me until I realized that the setup of the game is for it to be entirely played without a mouse, which is cool, but if you have a controller I suggest you use it for this.If you're looking for online Multiplayer though, you won't find it here, the multiplayer service is local (i.e two people would have to share the PC screen) but I don't blame the game for this as the original game on the consoles was also local and without online multiplayer connection. Though if you want to set up Steam Big Picture and grab some remotes, it's probably possible to mimic a console.

number of helpful: 16 of 17 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Lego Star Wars the Complete Saga came out in 2009 on PC and combined together Lego Star Wars the Video Game (1-3 episodes) and Lego Star Wars the Original Trilogy (4-6 episodes). No, Lego Star Wars 3 on Steam is a compltely different game. Aside from combining, it also changed gameplay in vehicle chapters of 1-3 Episodes, as well as adding bonus chapters, which include original versions of those vehicle levels. And well, let's just say that Lego Star Wars was quite a sudden hit when original came out in 2005, developed by Traveller's Tales, who made few charming games in the past and now are making Legos non-stop. Also, PC version has no online multiplayer. No Lego games on PC do.Technically it still works excellent. No glitches or crashes. Supports widescreen, as it should. It also works excellently with non-Xbox360 controllers, something that became quite rare nowadays.So, what is Lego Star Wars? Let's just say that it's one of the most casual games in action genre. There is no such thing as "game over". You can't die, you have infinite lives. The only thing that you lose is "stud", the currency of the game. Instead the game forces on collecting, unlocking, sillyness, humor and collecting and collecting. You got over 120+ characters to unlock, for example. And in each chapter 10 minikits are hidden. And often you can't get them all in Story Mode, instead having to use Free Play where you can change character to one of the few specially selected. Even though there are a lot of useless character or the ones who do same stuff, have same powers. But hey, this is what you get when the game tries to appeal to Star Wars nerds, putting every single character from background into it, while also making them stay unique in Lego shape.Game wants you to unlock some characters and then come back to the levels, uncovering all the secrets. There is probably too much of stuff to collect.And I must say though that the game, due to it's relaxy nature, can get quite repetitive for more classic gamers. After all, you can't die, you immeditly respawn in same spot. Penalty on Stud isn't huge, and people who don't care about unlocking anything just will not care. As a result of this, playing through all 6 episodes will get so old, that you will want it to end ASAP by Episode 6. One of those cases where game is too long for it's own good.Talking about story, it's probably slightly friendly to those who didn't watch Star Wars itself. Sometimes not. There is text before each chapter but the cutscenes are silent, instead being just about parody. Probably great for those who watches films first.And I got to say that 4-6 Episodes somehow were more interesting in story part than 1-3. Didn't see movies myself. Maybe people who kick the prequels aren't so wrong.The gameplay combines the action of fighting and puzzles in it, with some exploration for sake of gettin studs. Puzzles are quite varied. Sometimes you have to push a box. But most often it's about switching to the right character to open the door. Original trilogy got better there, making you take on a helmet to pass some doors. You don't have to get hit so the helmed will not get knocked off. Also, AI is pretty great there, as in cases where it requires 2 players, it will help you happily.Now, there is action, fighting part. You got either got a gun or lightsaber. Gun users can shoot with attack button. Some of them can avoid incoming shots if you press attack in a moment when the enemy laser shot is nearby. In such cases character will dodge and then aim at the one who shot it. So, spamming attack can win the battles there. Gun users can also use hooks to get into some areas.Lightsaber users can once again smash button to hit things. Hitting attack when somebody is about to hit you also makes your character block, also deflecting any laser back at attacker, so panicing by mashing attack can work there too. But they can also double jump and do area attack this way. Actually, you fight most bosses with Lightsaber character and most often the way that you can do damage on them is just spamming jump attack.And well, such simplistic nature of fighting should compliment the game that is mostly about puzzles and exploration for sake of collecting. The thing is, there is at times way too much fighting. And it doesn't help at all that AI refuses to help you any bit, only sometimes distracting enemy attention on itself. You feel quite alone in these cases.Actually it gets to completely frustrating moments by the end of a game. Like, after fighting a bunch of enemies, you just want to concentrate on puzzle solving to get into next area. But as you finally found that you have to move something with force, game decides that you spent your time too boring and spawns yet another bunch of Stormtroopers. By this time, you really don't want to fight them, because you know you will win by spamming attack button, you want to solve the darn puzzle already. And all of this while few AI characters stand dumbly around, doing nothing. If you try to do something with force, then suddenly every enemy will focus fire on you, so you sigh and just spend another 15 seconds on destroying them all.There are also vehicle missions where you fly around, spamming attack, collecting purple balls in one spot and then unleashing them on purple target. Most of them are like that. You can also play original versions of vehicle chapters in bonus levels, and boy, looking at them, they were much harder than you would expect from such relaxed game.Well, and graphics and music. Graphics are nice and fits well. It's hard to claim that Lego figures look unrealistical and lack polygons you know. Though, it feels too bright or blurry at times.Music is mostly same as in movies. I guess. It's either something forgetable, or arrangement of either Star Wars themes or Imperial March. Which is fine for movies. Not fine for games where you need more unique and memoriable tracks for each location. But hey, at least it changes between battle and peaciful music during gameplay.So yea. if you got two kids who love Star Wars and like collecting things, while being silly to each other, then it's perfect game right there. There is a reason why they say it's a game fo their childhood. And if you want more of traditional gaming values in it, then well, only expect to be amused.

content:
Posted: March 20
												Lighthearted and fun. I played the first three Episodes years ago on the Playstation 2, so when I saw a version with all 6 episodes I knew I had to pick it up.The game is great both for adults and kids, the story is slightly modified to keep it understandable in this format (the game features no voice acting - everything is grunts). I played it solo here, but I know that when I played it years ago, the co-op was great fun (the game was designed to have two players at all times - if you play solo the second player is replaced with an AI who automatically does their part in the teamwork puzzles but does nothing else).The game is broken up into 6 episodes (the original triology and the prequel triology) with each episode having 6 levels. Each level has a story mode. Upon completing each level, you also unlock the "Free Play" version of that level which allows you to revisit the level using any characters. Each level has a number of secondary objectives, most of which require you to visit the level in Free Play mode to use characters with certain abilities to access hidden areas, so once you finish the game on story mode, you still have a lot of content to explore!If you have kids, putting two of them in front of this is a great way of getting them to learn teamwork and puzzle solving.All in all, an extremely fun game.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												For those of you familiar with the LEGO series, here is one of originals that set the tone.For those of you who aren't, you have the cute LEGO figurines playing through a somewhat stylized version of the Star Wars Saga (episode 1 to 6), breaking LEGO pieces for studs along the way. After playing through in story mode, you can come back in free-play mode that allows you to switch between any character you unlocked. This allows you, for example, to use Princess Leia to grapple up to a ledge, and then switch to R2D2 to open a switch to open a door that was inaccessible in story mode. The game is easy but fun, and has a TON of collectables, unlock-able bonus levels, and such. Perhaps it is partially nostalgia, but this one ties LEGO Lord of the Rings for my favorite in the LEGO series.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												You might think that this game is like every other Lego game out there. And to be honest, you would be pretty much right. But. Because there is a but (there always is). It was the first of this kind of lego game. Or, more precisely, it is the combination of the first two, the Lego Star Wars games (duh).To those who played them separatly before, I say this : they took the first game, and got rid of what was infuriating to make it more diverse, like the second one is. And then they added the two games together, which means that you do not need to have a saved game of Lego Star Wars I to fight the Emperor with Jar-Jar and a young Boba Fett (I don't recommand trying that, btw).To those who have played other Lego games, I say this : it is no open world. It is quite linear at first. And there is nothing original here : you play through the movies. But it is funny, it is easy to beat (you get through the missions in under 3 hours), and you will go through it many times if, like me, you are a completionist.To those who have never played a Lego game, I warn you : if you happen to like this game, you might lose yourself in the Lego franchise. As I mentionned, it is quite easy to beat it "normally", that is to say finish the story mode. But that is when the real fun starts. You have much to unlock, discover, search... You can go back to any level to play it with unlocked characters, to look for secrets and secondary objectives. And that is without the bonus levels. Also : you see Vader show Luke a picture of him and Leia together to prove that they are related. Just saying.In short, it is well worth the price. If you happen to have an Xbox controler, that is. It is dreadfull to play with a keyboard (no mouse allowed). You have been warned.

												As far as LEGO games go, this game is definitely... well, a LEGO game.What I mean by this is that if you have ever played a LEGO game in your life then you already know everything there is to know mechanically about this game. In my experience, LEGO games are not so much about ground breaking, innovative gameplay; but rather, immensely enjoyable fun for the whole family that comes in all kinds of assorted flavors. Personally, I find the Star Wars flavor to be the best out of all of them, but for the same reason that a die-hard Harry Potter fan would tell you that the Harry Potter LEGO Games are the best.Overall, if you haven't ever played a LEGO game, then don't just buy the "latest and greatest". Buy a flavor you love, and I promise you won't be disappointed :)

Когда она только вышла, а это был 2009 год - год выхода на PC и "слияния" Lego Star Wars: The Video Game и Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy в одну игру, я купил пиратский диск в ближайшем магазине и побежал устанавливать и проходить. Сейчас уж не вспомнить, когда в последний раз я брал диск с какой-либо игрой в руки. И вот, игра запущена, идут всем знакомые начальные титры с также всем знакомой музыкой. Так как эта игра заточена под кооператив за одним компьютером, веселее будет конечно проходить вдвоём. Но мне не повезло, я играл один, но поверьте, получил море удовольствия лишь от того, что видел персонажей, локации и события в новой, не свойственной обёртке + доля фирменного теперь LEGO-юмора.Мнение об игре по пунктам  Графика Для тех лет сносная, 7/10   Сюжет За исключением первого эпизода, 9/10   Музыка Старина Джон - лучший, 10/10   Геймплей Помню были такие моменты, где я застревал надолго, 8/10 Средняя оценка - 8,5Да пребудет с тобой Сила. Всегда.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Being a compilation of the first two LEGO Star Wars games developed by Traveller's Tales, The Complete Saga stands resolutely as a lot of bang for your buck. Particularly if you're a completionist because finishing the game as-is will probably leave you at about 50% completion rate with plenty more to find in form of unlockable characters, gameplay gimmicks and additional levels. As a game it's your action adventure fare with platforming as you go through the entire movie hexalogy. I have to point out the game does suffer from having vehicle levels with extremely loose controls that simply end up getting in the way of things, though. The Complete Saga even retroactively adds some vehicle sections to prequel episodes to keep the entire experience consistent. It does benefits from eschewing voice acting in favor of simple gesticulation which leads to a lot of funny scenes as characters try to convey some plot points. Speaking of characters they operate based on different types ranging from Jedi and Sith aka Force users to droids and bounty hunters, each with their own specific utility which you will need to use in order to complete each level to its fullest. In practice this means you'll be going back to already finished levels in order to complete them as you unlock more characters. You'll also be spending omnipresent studs you gather throughout the game as currency to unlock things. This write-up may seem to be a bit all over place, but that's because I find myself fighting for words. It's a really great game and should not be dismissed as a cash-in game, not even close. Just beware – completionist mentality is recommended.

												I own this on PS3 and PC/Steam.  Highest possible recommendation for casual gaming (or obsessive collecting).  I am not a big Star Wars Prequel fan, but their least-irritating form is, surprisingly, their Lego gaming depiction.  Who would have thought back in the 80's while we were struggling to beat "Contra" on NES with only 5 or so lives that our favorite games in the future would be ones in which you can't really "die" or "lose."  All of these Lego games are only frustrating when it comes to 3D platforming at times, when it's hard to guess what depth the platform you are aiming for exists at, but overall, this is a great, comprehensive, varied, fun game.  I have experienced zero bugs with it.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												Don't let my measly 2.5 hours fool you, I have played this almost to completion on the Xbox 360. The two versions are practically identical save for maybe a higher framerate on PC. If you fear that the PC version is any different then you need not worry because it is just as good and I look forward to 100% this game.Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga is the six star wars movies told in lego form. Each episode is split into six chapters, so there are 36 levels of lego silliness to enjoy. Each level has different objectives like collecting enough money in each level to get "true jedi," collecting ten minikits to make a vehicle to use in other levels, and the red brick that gives you abilities to purchase (with ingame money, as it should be). On top of this there is free play, that lets you have fun in each level instead of playing the story, and even other levels outside of the original saga like challenge modes. There's a "super story" that tests how fast you can complete the six chapters in an episode in succession. So in terms of gameplay there is a lot to do.Lego Star Wars is definitley a completionists game, with things to collect wverywhere you go. There's minikits, red bricks, characters, true jedi, and lots of money. Your progress is tracked with a hologram by the shop in the hub world of Mos Eisley cantina. Even this cantina has loads of things to do like make custom characters, view ones you've unlocked, go outside the cantina and look at vehicles, and a two player challenge mode (everything in the game can be done with a local co-op partner).Given that this game was released in 2009 the graphics are dated compared to the Lego Star Wars: The Force Awakens game and others. There is also a lack of co-op over the internet.I would definitley recommend this game to people of all ages, people who like star wars, and completionists of all levels.

												The game you played as a kid is back! Journey through all six films and experience a story that is legend. There is no dialogue ripped from the films, a plus for prequel-haters. Lego isn't too keen on sales so just buy this one when you have the cash. I've bought this gem a total of four times.  The first two were on the PS2 (The game used to be split between the two trilogies), the third was on PS3 for that 1080p shine and merger of both games. Now it's found a home in my Steam library. With the addition of Vsync, graphics options, sixty frames per second, and 1080p screen resolution, I can safely say this is *the best version of Lego Star Wars*!

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												The Star Wars fanbase is a tumultuous one. At the time of Lego Star Wars’ release, the franchise consisted of a fantastic trilogy, an awful trilogy and a mess of other content of varying quality. There are various groups of Star Wars fans with different opinions—some defend the prequel trilogy wholeheartedly while others are more down-to-earth, insisting that there hasn’t been a good Star Wars film in over 30 years.One of the biggest strengths of Lego Star Wars is that it doesn’t seem reminiscent of either trilogy, instead bringing forth its own style of simple, family-friendly humour and simplifying down the plots of all six Star Wars film into a cartoony mashup of the popular sci-fi series and the equally popular line of children’s toys.In theory, it’s a bizarre concept, but in practice it works rather well. The Lego adaptations of the various sets and characters from the films look fantastic, providing a wacky, cartoony art direction complemented by the game’s child-oriented sense of humour. It consists mostly of slapstick comedy by way of over-the-top animation. In fact, the graphics overall are actually very good. While the ‘photorealistic-in-2005’ textures on some of the non-Lego environmental objects are a little ugly, everything that’s made of the titular plastic bits looks great. It’s quite amusing to see well-known icons of the franchise like the famous Millennium Falcon rendered as an excessively detailed Lego model.There is, however, a bit of a disparity in overall visual fidelity between the episodes taken from the original 2005 Lego Star Wars game and the 2006 sequel. The original trilogy characters taken from Lego Star Wars II each have unique animations and each has an exotic look about him. Han Solo winks knowingly at the camera as he twirls his laser pistol on his finger before he holsters it, Darth Vader simply taps his foot in front of security cameras rather than give the wave of acknowledgement an average Stormtrooper would. My favourite is the animation that plays when you try to punch Princess Leia as Lando Calrissian—rather than attack her, he plants a gentle kiss on her hand and bows. It’s the little details like this that make Lego Star Wars such a joy to look at.Characters from the prequel trilogy, however, all share the same set of generic animations. I didn’t notice any of the detailed animations with them, and there was even one character I noticed who kept the ‘generic Lego smile with soulless black eyes’ expression regardless of the situation he was in. It was unnerving and honestly just felt like a bit of a cop-out. I understand that these characters were from an older game, but I think if the developer is going to re-release both of these games in a package like The Complete Saga, the least that could be done is an update to bring these parts of the game up to the quality level of the original trilogy.Surprisingly, the quality gap doesn’t stop at the animations. Allow me to give an example. Characters from the original trilogy who use laser pistols have access to a ‘dodge’ move, allow them to quickly step out of harm’s way in combat. This feature wasn’t implemented in the original game, so the characters from it cannot use this ability. This is baffling laziness on the developer’s part, and it actually makes about a quarter of the game’s characters obsolete by comparison. It’s especially embarrassing when you consider how much effort it would take—all the characters are almost exactly the same model, and all the animations are already in the game. In fact, the entire amalgamation is rife with this kind of laziness. All that’s really been done to the original game's content is a slight graphical tweak. Don’t get me wrong, everything that’s here is fantastic, even the older stuff, but I just don’t quite understand why a developer wouldn’t take the time to even out the quality so that even the content from the 2005 game feels like less of a re-tread and more like a remake.The gameplay itself is essentially a 3D platformer with an emphasis on combat, puzzles and collectible items. The levels are beautifully rendered as Lego models, though there are a lot of models and textures designed to look like real-world objects. It’s a little disappointing that not everything’s made of Lego, but it still a treat to look at.The controls are sufficient. I did find that far too many actions are bound to the B button, and the vehicle-based levels are an absolute nightmare in general, but the ground-based levels control well enough. The combat is extremely simple—it’s not really viable to use more than two buttons—but I still found it engaging, perhaps because of the (mostly) superb animations.Lego Star Wars uses sounds taken almost exclusively from the films, and it works fantastically. John Williams' score speaks for itself, but it’s not even just that—every sound effect is authentic to the point where just listening to the game’s audio could leave you thinking you were actually watching one of the films. The way the characters collide with a soft click is so charming, and fits with the game’s overall style perfectly.The Complete Saga has a whole lot of content. There are 37 levels total, 20 side missions (given out by the illustrious Jabba the Hutt), 160 characters and a variety of vehicles. I do have a problem with the character roster, however. Out of the huge selection, there are maybe 8 that aren’t just remodels of other characters. To make matters worse, a lot of characters are just another character minus one ability. Every Jedi is identical, and every Sith is just a Jedi with an extra ability, thereby invalidating the need to ever play as a Jedi outside of story mode. There are a ton of other comparisons that can be drawn up, which I’d bet would invalidate over half the roster. I get that they want to include everyone from the films, but it feels like they could have buffed up a lot of the weaker guys. Sure, that may end up with most characters being reskins of others, but that’s still a better alternative to what happens now.On the topic of content, a lot of The Complete Saga’s replayability feels pretty contrived. For instance, within each and every level there are 10 ‘minikit canisters’ that will give the player a new vehicle once collected. The problem is, most of these canisters can only be acquired using abilities that the player does not have in story mode, thereby mandating a second playthrough of the level in ‘free play’ mode to reach 100% completion. ‘Free play’ mode is the same as story mode, but it removes the cutscenes and allows the player to choose one of their unlocked characters to play as throughout the level. They may then swap between a select group of characters on the fly. This party of characters is selected based on their abilities, ensuring that you will always have access to every ability in the game as long as you’re in free play mode. It’s good fun to go back through early levels searching for collectibles as Darth Vader (obviously the best character), but I just wish it didn’t feel so much like the game was trying to force multiple playthroughs. It’s a minor criticism, however. I still had a great time in free play mode.Overall, The Complete Saga does feel like a bit of a lazy compilation of two fantastic games, but I’m still going to recommend it based purely on the outstanding quality and unique style of those original games.

Posted: April 13, 2016
												This is a fun game but somewhat antiquated feeling if you've played the newer Lego games and then go back and play this. For those who may not know, this is a combination of 2 original titles - Lego Star Wars and Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy. I have played neither of those but from my understanding, their recreation in this "Complete Saga" is pretty faithful to the original games with some minor changes here and there. One of the nice bonus features is that they let you play the original version of 2 stages from the first game and you can tell that they definitely made some improvements in terms of the maneuvering and physics on those stages. However on one of the stages they also made it a lot easier by essentially removing certain goals that have to be met throughout the stage to continue.On the whole thoguh, if you've played most any Lego game before, then you know what to expect. If not, then expect to smash a lot of stuff, play as a lot of different characters from the Star Wars series and use those characters' various abilities to progress through stages and find the insane amount of collectibles, if you so choose. As with most Lego games, this game goes almost overboard on the sheer amount content and collectibles that you have to play and find to achieve 100% if you're a completionist like me. This one really almost wore me down and I feel that they maybe put a bit TOO much, but you certainly get your money's worth.All in all, if you're a Lego game fan and/or a Star Wars fan, I would recommend this game. It does a very good job of staying mostly faithful to the Star Wars movies, while taking some creative liberties in order to keep gameplay consistent. It also has the light-hearted humor throughout that the Lego games are known for and I think that Star Wars fans will appreciate most of it. Again though, be prepared for a slight feeling of antiquated controls and mechanics if you've played newer Lego games, sepcifically Lego Star Wars III: The Clone Wars because they have definitely continously made gameplay improvements over the years.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Takes me back to the days of playing this beautiful game on the PS2 and Wii. The PC version is basically the Wii version with PC optimisations, although I swear I can see some extra content in the PC version...The Wii version in and of itself was incredible, basically merging the original two PS2 games. In keeping with the Wii game, this is also incredible. It's fun, and a hell of a lot of it. At their core, Lego games are pretty basic: Get your Lego minifigures and go nuts in some themed setting, which appeals amazingly to children (Exhibit A being myself about 10 years ago). But the more intricate features (gold/power brick unlocks, challenge mode, etc.) are enough to keep more hardened gamers (Exhibit A being myself right now) coming back for more.And it's Star Wars. Jar Jar actually has a purpose in this game, and you can quite successfully fight Darth Vader with Darth Vader in Free Play mode.Brilliant game, and the nostalgia rush makes it even better.9.5/10

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												This used to be my favorite game many-a-year ago and I was afraid to return to it in fear that it would lose what had made it so entertaining for me. This game hasn't aged at all and I really did enjoy it. Before I knew it, I already had 3 hours logged on to the game! This game truly is one of if not the best Star Wars game you can buy. I've never reccomended another game as much as I can reccomend this one. I've logged over 200 hours on the DS version with less levels and features. This game includes many levels with puzzels that require different types of characters in order to get collectables and other objects in order to complete the game and to unlock secret areas and levels. Unlike other LEGO games, such as LEGO Indiana Jones, the puzzles are not tedious and not required for progression. Even with the game's cheat codes, the game is still as fun as ever and with no DLC, it is truly worth a buy.

												I bought this game purely for nostalgic reasons. But, after playing it again enough to remember why I used to play it in the first place, I realise that it holds up incredibly even today. The levels are fun and creative, the controls are tight even without a controller, and there's no feeling like immersing yourself as your favorite Star Wars characters. The amount of detail in this game is amazing. There are SO MANY things to do just around Mos Eisley cantina. Super good.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												This is the third LEGO game I've played, and I can definitely say they have improved over the years.  Unfortunately, that means that this very early one is missing a lot of the refinements that have been added as the series has developed.  While it still has the enjoyable LEGO rendition of familiar characters and scenes, as well as the trademark sense of humour, this particular game gets repetetive pretty quickly and lacks the variety of later games.  It's the first LEGO game where I couldn't be bothered to get 100%, mostly because that required replaying the same missions on a timer.  It was a good way to get ready for The Force Awakens, but it just doesn't measure up to Marvel Superheroes or the Harry Potter games.Also, I found it interesting that the prequels were just as boring and reprehensible in LEGO form as they were in the cinema.  I suppose that didn't help.In order to decide whether to recommend it, I imagined there were no other LEGO games.  On its own, it's good enough.  It's just nowhere near their later offerings.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												This brought me a lot of nostalgia, and runs very well as it should.  The gameplay is solid and has good humor.  However, the controls are rough if you're using a keyboard and mouse.There is no mouse support whatsoever, not even on menus.  You can rebind all the keys to any buttons on keyboards, joysticks, etc.  I highly recommend playing this with a controller or even a joystick.As with most Lego games, you can play local co-op on a single computer, which is a great feature.  Supsequently, there is no online co-op.  However, co-op is nearly impossible with a keyboard.  Essentially, one player uses one half of the keyboard and the other player uses the second half.  This isn't the issue though.  The problem is that regular keyboards cannot register more than 4 keys being pressed at the same time, so sometimes one player won't be able to attack or jump.  If you have a mechanical keyboard, this isn't an issue.  Ideally both players should have controllers, but either player can bind their controls to any kind of input peripheral.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												I bought all LEGO games on impulse and this was the first one that I played and finished. I have mixed feelings about it. While the thematic is amazing (STAR WARS!!!11!!) and it recreates all movies stories perfectly the game itself doesn't offer a real challenge and it is really annoying sometimes.Pros:- Thematic and story- Lots of humour- You can play with almost every Star Wars character- LOTS of things to find in every level- Friendly AI is impressive on some levels (pathfinding + actions)Cons:- Starship and flight controls and combat are really bad and stressful. Yes, the flight levels are awful. Actually I would say that vehicle controls overall are terrible in this game. - Music and Sound can be really annoying. I know we are talking about Star Wars music, but it just doesn't stop playing anytime.- The only challenge is to collect all coins (stud) to then buy stuff in the store, to get to 100%. I finished all levels and story mode with 27% and I don't plan on coming back to keep collecting coins just to buy some new characters.- Enemy AI is dumb most of the time.- Repetitive. On Episode VI I just wanted to finish it ASAP.I don't know if this is the default recipe for LEGO games, but the next LEGO game I'll play has to be a newer one with achievements, because I want to check if the mechanics and challenges have changed - but specially the vehicle controls. So I'll decide it the other ones that I own will be worth playing.Score: 6 / 10.TL;DR; Play only if you are a Star Wars fan or if you are a game completionist and like replaying the same levels over and over again to find and collect all stuff.

If you are thinking about getting into the Lego games, Lego Star Wars the Complete Saga is the one to start with.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												I played the original LEGO Star Wars on PS2 with a friend back in the day, and it was hella fun.I bought this, remembering how fun it was, and knowing I'd get the content from the second game that I'd never played, the decision was even more of a "duh".To my surprise, they actually changed some of the most frustrating aspects of the original.  The Mos Espa Podrace is now fully 3D rendered, no longer has a timer for each segment of each lap, and is far more forgiving about hitting obstacles, making it much less frustrating to play and much easier to get True Jedi on.  If you want to see what the original was like, it's available to play in the bonus section.Sorry I can't really go more in-depth, I just don't think I need to. I'm extremely happy that I can play this game again.  You get to play through all six Star Wars movies (even if only 4, 5, and 6 actually exist...), in LEGO style with plenty of humor thrown in.Also, YOU CAN KILL JAR JAR BINKS.  REPEATEDLY.  HOWEVER YOU LIKE.  WHY HAVE YOU NOT BOUGHT THIS GAME YET.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2012
												Here is the thing....this is a damn fun game.....I mean really really fun.  However before I sing the praises let me bring up two huge issues for me. One is the A.I. it is utterly inept.  You REALLY REALLY want to play with someone in co-op, as the A.I side kick does NOTHING.  NO help of ANY kind while you fight.  I am sure this is a result of wanting players to use the co-op feature.  An that is my second issue.  This really really is best served as a co-op play.  You will enjoy it far more if you play with a friend, the wife, the hubby, the kids...anyone but the A.I.  Now to recap the great here.  All Star Wars films, the original 4,5,6 and the prequel 1,2, and 3.  All here, all very in depth, insideously cute, and amazingly deep.  The collectable got to get every Lego alone is a 100 to 150 hours alone.  The reply value here is endless..... An for Any fan of Star Wars really needs to sit back, re enter the universe and do not be afraid to smile, and see it Lego style.  Enjoy, I am.

												For me, this game is a good ol' slice of nostalgia. If you haven't played the game, you should find some fun in the simple yet addicting gameplay with a bit of puzzle solving, and Star Wars fans should find some fun laughing at the jokes scattered throughout. The story convayes the plot of both Trilogies without any dialoug beside some grunting.There are countless new Lego games that are also great, but if you want a simple and old one, this is defiently worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2013
												For several hours I was pretty sure this was the best thing ever. It's just so incredibly charming in the way it presents everything, and absolutely everything is interactive in some way. As you wander through the Star Wars movies in hack and slash/pantomime form, just about all the props and set pieces can be smashed or prodded with character abilities to make something interesting or funny happen and get some sort of reward. It's extremely entertaining to poke everything and see what happens...at least through the prequel levels.Unfortunately, once I got to the original trilogy, the pacing completely fell apart. The levels went from being tightly constructed and bite-sized, which works extremely well with the density of stuff to fiddle with, to fairly long and tedious right when episode four hit. I'm not really sure I have the patience to keep going, which is a shame because when it comes to the movies themselves, I hate the prequels and was really looking forward to the second half of the game being even more amazing than the first half based on that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I once said, in another review, that I used to play Lego Indiana Jones with my little brother a lot when I was a kid, but it was difficult because of our lack of skill and faulty hardware at every level. Well, there's a secret backstory for that review, because I'm fairly sure that Lego Star Wars was the first game I ever played, and the conditions and brother were even MORE trying then. The disc and laptop were worse, we were younger and thus worse at games, the shared keyboard was even more compact, and we only ever got to play it on long car rides, where every bump on the road knocked the disc around in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ holder and spawned another game-breaking glitch. Truly a crucible of early gaming.Well, it wasn't the entire thing. The version we had was just Lego Star Wars 2, which was Episodes 4-6 (which happen to be the ones I just completed the story mode for). We didn't get the full package until a couple of years later, when it was one of the two games we got along with our new Wii for Christmas. To justify its existence as 2 games stapled together, it added a few new features, like new bonus levels, a 1v1 mode, and powerups scattered throughout the levels, all of which are fairly pointless. As to the levels themselves, episodes 4-6 are far stronger than episodes 1-3, for what I think are a few reasons: 1, more interesting things happen in the originals; 2, it came out a year later, when all the developers had finally earned their game design degrees; 3 (and this is complete speculation), the devs probably had more love for the originals than for the new ones; and 4, I have more nostalgia for the parts I played first and therefore those parts are better. Shut up, it's true.And as for the game itself? Well, it's not nearly as polished as Lego Indiana Jones (the devs clearly learned more the more games they made, which is a trend I support), but for what it is, it's fantastic. Coming back, not only was I realizing how much fun I was having in just the first level, but I was also experiencing almost crying levels of nostalgia for things that had all come rushing back from almost a decade ago. I remembered that puzzle with the crane! I remembered wanting to be R2-D2 or Captain Antilles! Oh my God! Rebel Friend! I remembered Rebel Friend!Anyway, nostalgic tangents aside, the same rules apply for this as they do for Lego Indiana Jones; everything's either good game design, funny and/or goofy, or probably broken (or John Williams's score). Tell you what, if I ever make a game, I'm going to hire all the animators from Traveler's Tales, because those guys know how to do an incredible amount with very little. Look up the intro cutscene for Episode 6, Stage 5. See how they convey all (or at least most of) the conflict and emotion of the scene in the movie, in the space of about 30 seconds, using absolutely no dialogue, with F*CKING LEGO FIGURES? These people are masters!Also, they managed to nail the vital Stormtrooper balance of adorably bad but taken completely seriously. You should buy the game for just that.P.S. If you think it's just a game for kids, go to the Zero Punctuation for Lego Indiana Jones and listen to what he has to say about kid-oriented vs. family-oriented. This one's family-oriented.P.P.S. Like the Indiana Jones review, I haven't played the whole thing through here but I did when I was younger, and I remember all of it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
 Not the best ever assembled, but creative I cannot tell you enough how much I adore this game. It is so funny to think that LEGO made a Star Wars game - and even better - it works! It totally works, and that's the beauty of it. It is easy to pick up and just as easy to plop it right down again (Yeah, stay right there on the ground!). LEGO Star Wars - The Complete Saga offers a fun and simple experience to enjoy alone or with friends. I had just as fun hacking away with my green LEGO lightsaber alone as I did with my brother. The gameplay mostly consists of building, fighting and figuring out simple but rewarding puzzles, while collecting addictive collectables and new characters from the expansive Star Wars-mythos. I love how these games aren't very hard but still so gosh darn rewarding. It's quite an achievement and I've liked it since I was just a little youngling myself.LEGO Star Wars - The Complete Saga gets a score of8/10 from me. I don't recommend buying it for it's full price, which is quite expensive, but if you manage to pick it up on a sale - trust me, you will have a good time.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												                                                                                            LEGO Star Wars                                                                                        The Complete Saga                                                                                     You have to play with                                                                                   this game because it's a		                                         		      real fun. Some says that LEGO                                                                           games are for children but i think                                                                          it's not true. Yes it's rather easy and                                                                    simple, but to achieve a 100% walkthrough,                                                                   you'll have to be patient and you have to use                                                                the Force. You'll gonna play the sxy episodes six                                                              levels (yes, it's 36) a numerous times. First in story                                                          mode, then in free play too. To get every hidden things                                                     you'll need special characters. To have the special characters                                                 you'll have to play throughout the story and need to collect bricks.                                               I played with this hundreds and hundreds of hours before discovered                                             Steam, and started to collect games. Since then my first priority was to                                           own this amazing game. Others say that you'll gonna die more times then                                       in Dark Souls, because of some control flaws. At first it is true maybe, but don't                                   let that bother you too much. If you love Star Wars and want to play something easy                               and funny (with a friend, boy/girlfriend, or just alone) i recommend you this game. For me                             it is THE video game, and an instant classic, maybe it will be for you too. Try it and decide for                           yourself. It is sale time so it is cheap. Once a Jedi, always a Jedi, or something like that. Peace...

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Kick Some Brick in I through VI Play through all six Star Wars movies in one videogame! Adding new characters, new levels, new features and for the first time ever, the chance to build and battle your way through a fun Star Wars galaxy on your PC! New Gameplay Features with enhanced Force Powers, new power-ups and new Challenge Modes. Solve Puzzles through the use of creative thinking, teamwork and unique building situations. Over 120 playable characters, and new characters like Watto, Zam Wessell, Boss Nass and more! Upgraded Character Customizer allowing millions of possibilities. With character parts from all 6 movies, create cross-Trilogy mash-up characters like Han Windu and Lando Amidala. Redesigned levels like the "Mos Espa Podrace" and "Gunship Cavalry" to take advantage of the the open vehicle gameplay of LEGO Star Wars II. Bonus levels and missions allow you to take 10 additional Bounty Hunter missions from Jabba the Hutt in the prequel trilogy. Two Player Local Co-Op lets friends and families play together.

												Okay, let me start by saying that I loved the original version of this game on the Wii. content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Story: Pros:- Follows the story line from the movies.- Lots of collectables to find after beating the game.- 13+ hours of story and up to 24+ hours of going for all collectables.Cons:- No dialogue.- Jumps through the story's fast.Split Screen:Pros: - Play with one other friend or sibling.- Access to the "Two player arcade".Cons:- No online- Not  "split screen" both players on one screen, no going opposite directions. Characters:Pros: - 160 induvidual characters from all six of the movies. (obviously no force awakens)- Indiana Jones.- Two fully customizable characters.Cons:- Can't think of a con. lolControls:Pros:-Lightsaber spam is good.Cons:- Not very good controls with keyboard + mouse. (controller recomended.)- Some levels that require you to do some parkour can be difficult.- When you have a large party of characters it can be hard to switch to the right one.Overall:The story mode is great, reliving all the starwars movies excluding force awakens with a lego cosmetic layout. The character sellection is great. If you like starwars and legos this game is a big recomendation. Only try to purchuse when it's on sale don't pay the full $20.7/10

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Watch out for that vicious bounty hunter Boba Fett, Luke. Did I ever tell you I fought his dad? He was hired to assassinate a senator me and your father were guarding. We kept bringing her around open windows and public areas in order to draw the would-be assassin out because we knew he had too much pride to just shoot her from long range. He had used his payment to hire another bounty hunter to kill the senator for him while he sent us on a wild bantha chase. Also the 2nd assassin used her payment to buy a robot to assassinate the senator for her. Did I mention the 2nd assassin was a shapeshifter? She could have been a good friend in disguise and just shot the senator for all we knew! Then the robot used its payment to buy poisonous bugs to release into the senator's room while she slept after lasering a hole through the window. It could have just lasered her too after that because we weren't watching her at all, but it already bought the bugs. So we sense the hostile life forms (not the robot) in the room and rush in and save the senator in the nick of time! Then I jumped out the window to chase the robot back to its owner! Luckily it didn't have a self-destruct function. Then we found the 2nd assassin and chased her across the planet, and caught her when she tried to kill us instead of shapeshifting and escaping. But to our surprise, Jango Fett was watching the whole thing instead of going to kill the senator while we were away chasing the bugs chasing the robot chasing the shapeshifter. He shot her with a poisonous dart instead of sniper blaster, and only her instead of shooting all of us or blowing all of us with a rocket or something, then he escaped with his tiny jetpack. Luckily for the senator, my good friend Dexterr Jettster owned a 50s dinner on Courscant that had Republic secrets on the menu along with cheeseburgers and malt shakes. We found the assassin and Mace killed him later, right in front of Boba. He was a good friend.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												I originally played this on the GameCube way back in the day. I loved it then and  I love it now. Even though this is just a LEGO game the lightsaber controls are some of the best in any Star Wars game making you truly feel like a jedi. Unfortunately the same cannot be said for the vehicle controls which are floaty, unreponsive and stiff. Thankfully though there are very few vehicle levels. The only other minor gripes I have with this game is the occasional frame rate drops and the camera which sometimes has a hard time keeping up, especially in mulitplayer. This is a great casual game that I'd recommend to anyone. I give it an 8/10.

												This game has everything thing you want, and things you didn't even know you wanted, but now want in other games.These things include:- Star Wars- Lego- A mute Jar Jar- Unlimited Lego money- One hundred percent replayability- Star Wars- Local Co-op- Star Warsand- LegoThe ONLY thing this doesn't have (which also is the only thing that is holding it back from a personal perfect score) is online multiplayer. I know, I know, I know, it never did and it doen't really matter. I just wish I could play this game with my friends online. I have played this game with my frends when it came first out on the Gamecube and we all had a blast taking turns, relaxing on the couch, and punching Jar Jar in the face. I remember coming home from school sitting down and playing it all night long and enjoying every minute of it. I know for a fact that I spent over 1,500 hours on it, and I'm glad I did. I wish I could go back to those times and even play it for the first time again. I know what I'm playing for the next forever.Overall I would give it a score of 9.95/10

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												+ colorful, pretty detailed graphics;+ satisfying platforming and collectibles hunting;+ music - just what you would expect;+ tons of unlockables;+ low requirements;+ makes the prequels look cool in its setting;+ simplistic, but effective storytelling;+ beautiful, open locations;- don't expect a challenge, apart from a few puzzles and some frustrating segments, it's easy;- Jar Jar.Fun for all ages. Recommended.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												I never played the original LEGO Star Wars games when they first came out. Coming from having played some of the more recent LEGO games (LoTR, Marvel Superheroes), I can definitely see that the games have improved over the years.Compared to the newer games, the easiest way to describe this game is annoying. There's a lot of endlessly respawning enemies in almost every level and not much you can do about them until you get to freeplay.The hub world is cramped with no way to open the character roster to try out the characters you've unlocked without actually freeplaying a mission. Sometimes you can find the character you want wandering around the cantina if you get lucky. In freeplay, you have a tiny subset of your unlocked characters you can bring, of which all but 2 are chosen randomly so you probably won't get to play with your favorite characters.Your AI controlled teammate does ZERO damage to enemies and is at best a distraction since the enemies focus almost exclusively on the player anyways. You're effectively punished for playing solo.The difficulty (until you unlock cheats) is firmly on the side of annoying. The penalty for dying is minimal so it's not really difficult, but it's still not fun to be getting shot at by a dozen different enemies focused exclusively on you, interrupting you left and right and killing you frequently until you do whatever is needed to stop the respawns or move to the next area. On the other hand, the auto deflect cheat with exploding blaster bolts is immensely satisfying once unlocked.Vehicle missions are awful. Controls are terrible, and there's way too much running back and forth through endlessly respawning swarms of enemies to pick up torpedoes or (even worse) tow a bomb to a target.There's a lot more content reuse (game time is padded with an extra challenge mode for each level where you can't use extras) but it still counts towards 100% completion.There's a very annoying bug where the game effectively freezes for a few seconds every once in awhile. This is on a modern PC with dedicated graphics and a SSD.Much of this is forgiveable (except for the bugs) since this is simply a remastered version of the games that started this (mostly) wonderful collection of TellTale LEGO games. The newer games have improved upon these issues, and the newer games with the huge overworlds are surprisingly fun open world games.I can recommend this game based on the humor and for anyone who wants to complete their LEGO game collection, but unless you've got some seriously strong rose colored glasses on the gameplay falls short compared to the newer games.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Seeing how LEGO Starwars and LEGO Starwars II for the Playstation 2 were one of my more early childhood gaming experiences, I couldn't believe that they combined them both. When I looked into it more, I thought, "Heck yeah! I could be General Grevious and Boba Fett ANYWHERE!" so I bought it. Some might be thinking "what's the point to buying another game that consists of two other games?" Well, some parts of levels are changes with new mechanics, and there are even more levels you can play (consisting with 6 chapters in Attack of The Clones instead of 5, bounty hunter levels where you go on the hunt for characters throughout the levels, and extra levels which you unlock using the Gold Bricks you have aquired throughout playing.) Yes, I do admit, the game is somewhat slow when you begin it, but once you unlock some stuff, it's a blast. If you are looking for a challenge and only a challenge, these may not be the droids you're looking for. This game is more of a casual, relax time of game consisting of collect-a-thon with combat and exploring elements built in. If you want to get the maximum experience of the game, go for "True Jedi" by collecting a certain amount of stud in each level, also find all ten minikits in each level (which requires free-play) find all red-bricks, and do the challenges the game offers you (Blue minikits and speedruns of movie). This game's presentation is absolutely amazing. All of your favorite characters in LEGO, and you get to play as most of them. The cutscenes could use voice acting to improve them, but overall, they are entertaining to watch, and they look very clean. Also, The Prequels are actually tolerable now since you dont have to play as Anakin hating sand, and boring hour-long consle meetings. I am somewhat disappointed that you cant play Anakin's side of the story much in Revenge of the Sith, it would be cool to be the bad guy for a couple levels. But overall this is a very good game I extremeley reccomend it to any Starwars and/or LEGO fan.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
LEGO® Star Wars™: The Complete SagaPros:- 120+ characters from all I-VI episodes- 5 fun and amazing levels in each episode through I-VI- Simple game but very fun- Unique levels like the podracing level- Puzzles are fun and simple- Bosses are very cool and unique- Cutscenes are funny and great- Bonus levels from Jabba the Hutt and moreCons:- Keyboard support is garbage, get a controller- Jar Jar Binks :PConclusionIn all seriousness, for me the game doesn't have any cons besides the horrible keyboard support, its a classic, most of the people played it first on Wii or DS and then we played it on PC. I hope LEGO® STAR WARS™: The Force Awakens, gets a lot better and taking notes of this one, definitely one of my favorite games of all time.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												This is a very cute, fun game that is best played with 2 people. It does outline the stories of the first 6 films, but there's a whole bunch of other content in there (unlockable characters, vehicles etc.) that can be used in Free Play mode (play as anyone you like) or Challenge Mode (for you serial game clockers who need to have 100% completion). The controls are intuitive and despite the fact there's no dialogue, you know what to do during missions. ****

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												The game overall is good. But there's a bunch of problems that are making me think that I've wasted my ♥♥♥♥ing money buying this.1. Friendly Ai's don't do ANY sort of damage to the Enemy Ai.I've had this stupid thing happen to me all the time. The worst incident was on the death star and the Hoth mission. I had to build something to get to the next part of the level, but it was extremelly hard due to the fact that the AI's can't do ANY sort of damage towards the Hostile Ai's. It took me a total of 2 or something hours just to get through the Death Star mission, just because of that.2. You stop building when you get shot.This is quite annoying, when you have to build something and there's a bunch of guys shooting at you, the AIs you are set with cannot do any damage and cannot protect you. If you're shot while building, you'd have to start all over again.There's many more problems, but I cannot be bothered to list them all. These are all of the problems I have ran into as of right now. I would reccomend this game, although the problems  are fairly annoying.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												This game was my childhood. I'm biased of course, but I think this is a really great game whether you have nostalgia for it or not. For me, now I'm able to relive those blessed afternoons playing this on the WII- "Let me be Darth Vader!" "Stop throwing bombs at me!" "GO FASTER SEBULBAS GETTING AWAY"It's a lot easier than I remember it- when I played this as a kid I paid a friend to beat Mustafar for me (he couldnt but still took my money). Now each level is pretty much 20-30 minutes on story mode. The game isnt really a challenge (aside from the bonus levels that ravaged my village when i was a child). I mean, it's sometimes tricky to get the minikits but never infuriating. There are some parts that feel very dated (I'm looking at that cutscene of the Slave 1 "taking off" on Kamino), but in an odd way the small bad parts are endearing. Let's just say you can tell it's aged, but it aged with dignity.Bugwise, it's pretty clean. Good port. The only issues I have are the dumbass controls for p2 (if you don't have a controller) and the friendly AI not dealing damage. That's something I don't remember from back in the day, I remember relying on them to pick off stragglers? Also droidekas are overpowered as hell and it's BS to die twice doing the only lightsaber move that kills them, and also BS because you're basically invincible when you play with them.Word from the wise, on the Hoth Ice base level with Han and Leia there's a part with a bunch of fans and a little truck that's practically impossible without P2 controlling C3P0, which means you either need to get a friend or grow another arm. That's actually the only gameplay issue I've seen, and I remember it infuriating the hell out of young me.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												I am at a loss for words with this game. I am literally speechless. This is THE perfect game. With its fun and memorable levels, tons of different characters, bonus content, hilarious hijinx, and the ability to play as LEGO minifigures, how can you go wrong. I actually own both of the previous installments that make up this game(Lego Star Wars) and (Lego Star Wars 2 The Origional Trilogy), and yet I knew I still wanted this game just to see everything collide. This game built up my expectations and knocked them completely out of the park. One of the key factors of this game that I don't think other lego games of our time have are the fun, and not to be redundant but, memorable levels, characters, and events that all can be linked to the origional source material. Traveler's Tales really outdid itself with the creation of this game. As an ENORMOUS Star Wars enthusiest, it makes me feel so glad how much effort and tlc was put into this game unlike others who purchase the rights merely to sell basic games just under the name of "Star Wars". This is one of the only games I actually reccomend to all people for its amazingly fun and sometimes addicting gameplay and its intensly immersive experience. I of course, give this game a ten out of ten for its sheer creativity, fun loving characters, truity to the films, immersive environents, mesmerizing mechanichs, and most importantly, its impact on how I see the art of Gaming.
