number of helpful: 11 of 44 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												LEGO Star Wars: Prepare to Die (and again and again) Edition. TL; DR – If you are in doubt which Lego Star Wars game to buy, buy The Clone Wars. It‘s shorter (18 vs 36 story levels) but vastly superior game.I am huge Lego and Star Wars fan. This game is a big disappointment and very frustrating. I will talk about NEGATIVES.1) Driving and flying is f.cking dogs.it! You read it right. There is no difference between gamepad and keyboard controls. Both are utterly terrible and almost broken. I hated every mission with it.2) Who the f.ck thought that putting unskipable videos is great design?! Watching the same scene again and again… The main problem is some of them are just too long and you can‘t skip it. If you Alt-Tab it just pause and continues when you come back. 3) This game is ment to be played in co-op mode! Single player experience is terrible and very frustrating in the some half of missions. Let me explain. Your co-op AI is just useless and brain dead. They can only help you when you both need to push lever or jump on platforms to move. Full stop. Yes, they suck up blasters, but they can‘t kill anybody and they aren‘t even that good at sucking up blasters because you are going to die a lot. Again, a lot of dying. You want to construct something from blocks? Too bad you just died from blasters. "But just kill enemies." No you can‘t if they are on another platform and they just spawn again even when you kill them. Beyond terrible. That‘s why you need real co-op partner to shield you so you can do stuff.This game is aimed to children and yet you constantly die! It‘s very hard to collect studs for True Jedi because when you die you lose them. F.ck you from the bottom of my heart!OK I get it, in the past Lego games mostly sold in Nintendo systems, so it‘s logical that father and son played co-op, but please, this disaster could be mitigated if co-op AI wasn‘t passive! And guess what, co-op AI in Batman The Videogame is not passive.4) I really don‘t like Ep I-III movies, and yet in game those episodes are vastly superior gameplay wise. I even replayed them for additional mini kits. There are no words which can describe how much I hated most of missions in Ep V and especially VI! I replayed none of EP V and VI missions.There are positives: 1) humor is absolutely fantastic (see my screenshots) and2) music is great but what SW game doesn‘t have it?All in all, bad game :-/.EDIT Fanboy brigade downvoting like cra.y and yet nobody challenged facts.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												I absolutely LOVED lego star wars games as a kid. I have fond memories of playing them on the PS2 when I was younger.Going back to them now after roughly 7-10 years though, they are sadly nowhere near as good as I remembered them being as a kid.My main problem is with Disney, who owns the rights to the Lego Star Wars games. They are total money-grabbing jerks whose business practices I daresay are even worse than Rockstar Studios (we all "fondly" remember the sale scams Rockstar did the past few steam sales, where they jacked up the base price of GTA5 so that the "sale" price would be no different from the normal price). This game hasn't gone on sale in YEARS and there is no sign that DIsney has any plans on selling this fairly. Now if this was a brand-new Lego game with cutting-edge graphics, really good gameplay and a long storyline, i'd definitely say the selling price is fair, but there is absolutely NO justification for selling this 10-year-old game for 20 freaking dollars. It's a total ripoff.Now that I've got that off my chest, let's move on to the pros and cons of the game.PROSLiterally hundreds of different Star Wars characters to play asClassic Lego feelEnvironments are quite interactiveCombines the 1st and 2nd Lego Star Wars games into 1.CONSGraphical quality has deteriorated significantly over the years. The Prequel Episode levels are virtually unchanged from how they were back in 2005. The PlayStation 2 graphics are real.No online MultiplayerGame is specifically designed for young children. The gameplay is just so uninteresting if you're an older person like me that it's almost impossible to stand playing this for longer than a dozen hours or so.The game dogmatically insists you play in Co-Op mode, as the AI for the secondary player is god-awful to have to complete levels with alone (they dont do jack to help you out in combat, and just sit there letting themselves get shot at).Poorly-designed flight/racing levels have incredibly frustrating gameplay, with constant running back and forth and constant dying (especially on the Geonosis gunship combat level).The camera system the game uses is god-awful for telling what you're doing. It's incredibly easy to misjudge jumps and where your position is when platforming. Also it makes it really hard to see what you want or need to see in the environment around you.Flight controls for the racing/flight levels are god-awful. Making sharp turns when you need to fly over a specific object (eg. money, torpedo stockpiles) is practically impossible as the game instead just makes you do a sharp, huge 180 flip and go in the opposite direction. It's awful for maneuvering in tight spaces, and since colliding with the walls does damage, it makes unintentionally dying a massive issue. It can also undesirably launch you into the path of dangerous weapons fire when you just wanted to turn, which is also very bad. I can't count how many times I died due to this god-awful flight control system on the Geonosis map, or on the Coruscant Speeder Chase map.Gameplay becomes extremely repetitive and uninteresting from the very start. 90% of your time playing on levels is just spent running around destroying or messing with stuff to get more money/studs, and then running around in a frenzy trying to pick up as many studs as you can before they abruptly disappear.No real worthwhile objective to work toward in the game except getting more money and more lego characters. No meaningful or interesting story to want to complete, as it's all the same repetitive crap every map and every level, with constant unwarranted deaths in a mad scramble for getting as much studs as you can.The awesome Lego City map from Lego Star Wars 2 has been basically chopped in half with the most interesting parts taken out, and that's the Lego City map on this game. It absolutely sucks. They got rid of the boat and the lake (my favorite part), as well as some other fun buildings and locations.All in all, this game was perhaps fun to play back 7 or 8 years ago but it has since lost a lot of its replay value, and will easily come across as boring and bland to anyone above the age of 12. I'd only recommend buying this if you have a super bad case of nostalgia (but even then I guarantee you will be disappointed when you play this).

												This game's crisp, clean graphics have aged wonderfully and depending on how OCD you are (completionist or not) this game can actually be pretty hard.  The charming, nostalgia-inducing environments and music make this game a gem for lifelong Star Wars fans like me.  If you can get the Complete Saga for a good price and you're on the fence, go ahead and grab this.  Don't expect amazing combat, but a fun journey through a creatively designed, tongue-in-cheek and surprisingly lengthy game world.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												I have previously sung the praises of the LEGO games and this goes right back to where it started. It already has the key ingredients of the success of the later games. It has the silly retelling of the story. It has the varied character abilities that allow you to replay each level and find hidden stuff. It has the mini-kits to collect, the red bricks that unlock new abilities. It has the bonus levels and the 2 player cooperative focused gameplay. All of this is great.However it really isn’t as polished as the later games. It does not have split screen so your two characters are awkwardly, invisibly tethered together making the cooperative mode very frustrating. And conversely there are a few sections of the game which didn’t work well when playing on your own as your AI partner gets stuck or refuses to do what is necessary. Character switching is annoying as you have to be right next to the character you want to switch to and the ship controls are rubbish.My main complaint is just how many times you have to repeat levels. You play through the level in the story and then again in free play with any characters which is fine. However the game then makes you play the level again to find a new set of canisters against the clock and then again to play all the levels in a film in one go against the clock. So if you complete each level perfectly first time you have to repeat every level 4 times but if you play without consulting a walk through you are likely going to have to play each level 7 or 8 times. Also once you have bought all the bounty hunters there unlocks a bunch of Jabba the Hut missions that, yes you guessed it, involve you playing through sections of most of the levels again. This is the first time I have failed to 100% complete a LEGO game because after spending an hour grinding my way through the entirety of Empire Strikes Back and just failing to complete it within the time limit, I just thought ♥♥♥♥ this I have better things to do. Overall this established the massively successful formula that paid off in later games but as far as this game goes in its own right it is disappointing. I’d only really recommend this if you are a big Star Wars fan. Maybe if you have never played any other LEGO games then you would enjoy this more, then you can play other ones and see the improvement.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
The ProsThis gem has lasted 10 solid years, providing a memorable spitscreen, pick-up-and-play approach that makes it fun to play with others.  The story mode itself has brief, adapted cutscenes from the actual films that make me feel warm inside.  Combine that with a vast array of characters, unlockable (not downloadable) content, quality sound, and a lovable asthetic; and you've got a solid 20 hour experience that will stick with you for a while.The ConsI said it's a gem, but even gems get dirty.  While it shines in sheer quantity of gameplay and multiplayer, the game has a few other problems.  It feels slightly dated, even though it's very similar graphically to any other recent LEGO release.  As someone no longer in elementary/middle school, the controls feel a little clunky, the combat overly-simplified, camera angles frusterating, and overall experience underwhelming.  I loved piloting the X-wing on the surface of the LEGO Death Star, but had no clue what I was really doing and just held down the fire button.My VerdictThough it pales in comparison to other games (Like Marvel Super Heroes) by simply feeling dated, I genuinely believe that it's a game that everyone deserves to experience.  Grab it when it's on sale, a friend, and play for a few hours to feel like that 6th-grade stud hoarder everyone is inside.  Instructions not included.7.5/10

												Where it all started. LEGO® games really picked up when the first game, covering the original trilogy, came out, and from there on, none missed the beat. Gameplay is now concidered basic, but it isn't so basic as to make this boring, leaving a serie of levels that brim with the kind of magic we've learned to love. Humor at every turn fills the cutscenes, the secrets are well hidden, collectibles aplenty, characters out the wazoo.Recommended for: Fans of the LEGO® games that want to experience the origin of it all, fans of Star Wars® games.

												Lego Star Wars the Complete Saga is a fun game. The missions / levels can be beat relatively quickly if you don't bother with the collectables. Collecting things in the game actually serve a purpose besides 100% completion.+36 missions / levels+All missions are based on parts of the Star Wars movies (1-6)+Graphics / artwork look nice+Very replayable+Dozens of characters to play as+Supports two players on the same computer+Controller support+You can customize two characters how you like+Lots of stuff to collect on each level-Gameplay can get repetitive after a few play throughs-No mouse support (camera is controlled by the game)-Very minimal graphic options-No achievements (console versions included them)

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Where it all started. LEGO® games really picked up when the first game, covering the original trilogy, came out, and from there on, none missed the beat. The second game, covering the prequels was incredibly fun, if frustrating. Gameplay is now concidered basic, but it isn't so basic as to make this boring, leaving a serie of levels that brim with the kind of magic we've learned to love. Humor at every turn fills the cutscenes, the secrets are well hidden, collectibles aplenty, characters out the wazoo.Recommended for: Fans of the LEGO® games that want to experience the origin of it all, fans of Star Wars® games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												When I was young, we got Lego Star Wars on PS2 and I loved it. It was kind of my introduction into the Star Wars universe, to be honest. I preferred the first one simply because I was more familiar with the prequels at the time (ew, I know), and I'll always miss the original Lego Star Wars hub, Dexter's Diner.Anyway,The Complete Saga is a wonderful combination of the (first) two Lego Star Wars games. It adds Red Bricks to the original prequel levels, new characters etc, you know the drill, you read the product description. It essentially acts as a PC port / HD remake for the best games in the Lego video games franchise, and you should absolutely buy it whether you played it in the past or not. If you miss the platformer days of the PS2 era - that is to say, collectibles, fun combat, the occassional puzzle, unlockable characters, no rubbish DLC - this is the game for you.It pretty much never goes on sale, but I'd say it's worth £15.Also, you can create your own C3PO with a droid head and Sith powers, so that's pretty rad.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2011
												Lego Star Wars? WHY would ANYONE buy this game? Well I'll tell you. Pure. Sheer. Simple. Fun. I loved Lego as a child and having it in video game form is no different. You can play co-op with someone (not online thankfully) and have the time of your life as Traveller's Tales successfully manages to blend the joy of Lego and the entire Star Wars movies into a hilarious game. The presentation is top stuff and the brief cutscenes have great delivery and humour which will leave you chuckling. Bring out your inner child and don't expect some crazy supah dupah stuff. Buy this game for fun and it will deliver. Replayability... oh gawd, now that will take you most likely hundreds of hours. There is so much packed into this game and so many goodies to find that you'll be foaming at the mouth at all the collectables. So what are you waiting for? Want fun? Buy this game!

												Its often hard to recommend a game without any negatives (only one, and yet its minor enough to barely mention it), and yet.. Lego Star Wars does just that. A childhood summoned up through all the movies, all the characters and more -- this game hits the nail on the head for exctiment, gameplay value, and especially replayability. 50+ playable characters from Vader, Yoda, to a Droideka. Many famous levels such as Hoth, Deathstar, etc. I cannot recommend this enough. The amount of hours you will put in, going back, doing a new area with a new character is just staggering. The story has qurky humorous moments that genuinly made me chuckle and many secerts that were a blast messing with. Overall, a very, very, amazing game.Pros+Extreme replayabilty+Travel across many famous locations in the star wars universe+A TON of characters to play as (50-100?)+"extras" earned let you cheat alittle or make the game easier. Great for kids+Nice moments of humorNegatives-Odd keyboard controls (No Mouse support ingame)

												I used to play this game after school at a friend's place, and I mainly bought this game for nostalgia's sake. This is one of the 'classic' lego games out there, from the time where the characters would only hum, instead of actually speaking, which gives it a very distinct look and feel.The local co-op is a lot of fun to play (with controller support, for those interested). It'd have totally rocked if it also offered online co-op, but at the time this was released, online multiplayer in such games was not yet such a common feature, and it's of course a lot more fun to use the force on your buddy's character and then laugh at him right next to you ;)I'd recommend this game to anyone that's at least a bit into Star Wars, and is looking for a fun game to casually play. It's family friendly (3+), so playing it with your brother/sister won't be a problem. Just buy it. It's awesome!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												I took a trip back to my childhood with this game and I gotta say: playing through both LEGO Star Wars games in one collection is pretty neat. I still remember the novelty of battling across the stars with my friends as we discovered the secrets of Free Play mode in every level. Tt Games really nailed replayability in these games, encouraging players to return to previously inaccessible areas of a level by using unlockable heroes with their special abilities. One thing has to be said about the original LEGO Star Wars, though: it hasn't held up especially well. I found the sequel to be the much more enjoyable and memorable of the two thanks to its clever level design and quirky humor. The first game is noticably slower paced and lacks the visually gags that add so much to its sequel. Regardless, it was nice to take a trip down memory lane and remind myself what all successive LEGO franchise games built themselves upon.It's really hard to say no to a package that packs in so much content. Hundreds of iconic Star Wars characters and tons of replayability keep me coming back for more from the galaxy far, far, away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												This game is one of my favourite games, having played it as a kid for hundreds of hours, so i might not be completely unbiased, but man, this game. It takes you through all the original 6 star wars movies in a very unique lego-y way, with each episode/film split into six parts; every part is one level, taking approximately 20+ mins to complete. The main storyline takes about 20 hours or so to complete, and is fairly simple (apart from some details you might miss about what you have to do). But the game does not just hand everything to you. To get really OP, you need to replay levels and discover every little detail and corner you could not explore with the story mode team, basically just completionism. This is completely optional though, so don't freak out. There's just so much to this game. From the amazing music with the original soundtracks, to the small little details like lando kissing leia's hand when pressing the action button, to the cheesy lego humor, to the big variety of characters to unlock, to the overall star wars-feeling overall; this game is simply a joy to play. (I found airship levels to be particularly enjoyable, with an amazing feeling to them) Admitted, combat is kind of lame, and the graphics aren't fantastic due to the fact that it is a 10 years old lego game, but the game is still enjoyable. The last complaint I have about it is that money is annoying to pick up sometimes. That's it. For a ten year old game, that's not that bad i would say, so go buy it.Tl;dr version:+game has loads of unlockables and secrets +great music+airship levels are great+option to play hard or even extremely hard levels, but easily playable normal levels+a sh** ton of small details that make the game so much better+easy playability; even a brick could handle this game-Graphics are not always the best-combat is fairly easy-money is annoying to collectStraight 8.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Lego Star Wars is a game I consider a classic from my childhood and the Star Wars VII hype got me to pick up this game in the Winter sale (Damn you marketing tactics!). This doesn't mean I think it's one of the best games I ever played as a kid but it's one I have very fond memories of and pretty much anyone I talk to about it has played it at some point. It's that perfect blend of co-op, collectathon, movie tie-in that's just great to play when I'm not feeling something very intense and just want to relax. The game is most certainly flawed, the artificial difficulty and lack of any complex combat is the one of the big complaints; I never felt challenged playing this game but I also died a lot because the game throws enemies at you non stop and while they only take one hit to kill avoiding all the blaster bolts can prove annoying if you aren't a character with auto dodge. This really slows down the game and while I don't expect the most from the combat every lightsaber battle was jump attack, jump attack, jump attack ect. It's impossible to hit someone while they're blocking with anything other than the air attacks which are undodgeable by the AI if you're in range. I know this is a kids game and not meant to be challenging but after a while even kids would find this tedious at best.The lack of online co-op is my biggest grind with this game. At first I thought it was an issue with it being such an old game that relies on single screen co-op but after checking other Lego games I realized that it was nothing more than a trend of laziness. I did manage to take my laptop to a friend's and play it with them and it was great fun except that save files are harder than needs be to locate and impossible to get working on a separate machine to the one it came from meaning we had to start a fresh with none of the cool characters I'd unlocked. Besides some of the vehicle levels being a bit lackluster and Superstory being total BS and a lazy way to recycle content these are my only real complaints with the game so from here on out it's all positive. The Lego formula has practically been perfected now but that doesn't mean it wasn't always great. Star Wars has so much charm in its cutscenes and is very humoresque due to it's recognizable and lovable characters acting out the Star Wars story in a silly and joking way. There is so much to do in this game and so much to find. While some levels practically hand you the collectibles some can prove a real challenge to find, but if your smart you can aim to collect the stud multipliers and minikit/red brick detector red bricks giving you a hint on in which direction there is a collectible. There's also some extra game modes in the complete saga that add that make 100%ing this game a real journey as you try collect all the gold bricks.One of the best things about Lego Star Wars is that it's well, Star Wars. Playing all your favourite Jedi battle it out on all those great planets from the Star Wars universe is immensely entertaining and even more fun in Lego. I would enjoy this game even if it wasn't Star Wars but the real heart and charm of the game comes from seeing your favorite scenes re-acted in Lego form. There were dull moments while playing this game but I thoroughly enjoyed it and I felt both a sense of fulfillment and emptiness once I reached 100% which shows just how great this game is. May the force be with you all.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												There are two things I do not understand:Why people say that keyboard controls suck when they're changeable.ANDWhy people think that you need the mouse on this game.The game only uses six buttons other than for movement. Two of these are only useful in Free Play and are never needed urgently.One hand can cover movement and two buttons. That leaves two fingers on your other hand that have to be somewhere on the keyboard. The other two that you never need quickly could be put right near them so you can use a third finger and then MOVE one of the others to press the other button should you need it. Or use all four fingers, whichever is easier.Seriously though, it's a game with incredibly simple controls and so very straightforward, you don't need a mouse or controller to play this game and enjoy it. It sits alongside LEGO Indy 1 and LEGO Batman as the Golden Trio of LEGO games before they started adding the horror that is voice acting in a series that prided itself on mimed slapstick retellings of famous stories. (Or mimed slapstick tellings of original stories starring Batman).Nominated for "The Test of Time" award.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I originally had the Lego Star Wars the Video Game on my GameCube. It was part of my childhood. Unfortunately, I never bought the Original Saga of Lego Star Wars. This thing has them both, with a bunch of connecting details. Instead of two separate games in one bundle, they are truly combined into just one game. For example, you have to be a Stormtrooper to access areas in Episode I, II, and III. It's a joy to be able to purchase this beauty on Steam and play it with a controller. The ability to relive some of my childhood memories with a boost in the graphic quaility is amazing! I always played Lego Star Wars on older TVs, so it feels odd to see it with a 1080p resolution and higher framerate. If you want to play a Star Wars game that has a TON of content and replayability, this is certainly a viable option.There is nothing serious about it! It really is just a playground of Star Wars fun. XD

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												I took a trip back to my childhood with this game and I gotta say: playing through both LEGO Star Wars games in one collection is pretty neat. I still remember the novelty of battling across the stars with my friends as we discovered the secrets of Free Play mode in every level. Tt Games really nailed replayability in these games, encouraging players to return to previously inaccessible areas of a level by using unlockable heroes with their special abilities. One thing has to be said about the original LEGO Star Wars, though: it hasn't held up especially well. I found the sequel to be the much more enjoyable and memorable of the two thanks to its clever level design and quirky humor. The first game is noticably slower paced and lacks the visually gags that add so much to its sequel. Regardless, it was nice to take a trip down memory lane and remind myself what all successive LEGO franchise games built themselves upon.It's really hard to say no to a package that packs in so much content. Hundreds of iconic Star Wars characters and tons of replayability keep me coming back for more from the galaxy far, far, away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga was one of the first video games in the LEGO franchise I played and which made me come back and play more LEGO games and now this title again. That being said, I find 60% of the time I spent on the 2007 title I was hard-pressed not to put the game for good. Controls and scripting have improved so much with later games that it is just a hassle to deal with their state in this game. Plus, I don't understand how over a decade after games came to PCs there are still unskippable cutscene.Recommendation: I started to play this game because it's a LEGO game and kept at it because I like to 100% a game. If you think, that description fits you as well and you are prepared for some discouraging game design, I'd say, go get the game. Same if you think you're satisfied with only going through the story missions once - this was quite fun. Otherwise you may just want to get a newer LEGO game. They are objectively better.+ LEGO game+ The Star Wars saga retold+ Loads of characters from the Star Wars universe (+1 extra)+ Lots of levels- Outdated controls- Immaturely scripted "player 2"- Immature camera / point of view- Flying missions include long and unnerving sounds- Unskippable cutscenes- I repeat, unskippable cutscenes- Reward collection policiesBrace yourself. What follows is as much a review as a rant, read as psycho hygiene, and thus may transport negative feelings.Why "60% of the time"? Well, it took me about 40% to get through the story mode, the rest of the time was spent bringing the savegame to 100%.The game has an in-built requirement for replaying levels if you want to get to 100%. AFAIR each story level, and there are many, requires the completionist to play it at least four times. There are quite a few levels outside the story, a welcome diversion. Replaying levels, of course, also restarts the connected cutscenes. Of those you can skip the very first story cutscene, which is directly followed by another cutscene you cannot skip. Throughout each level you'll encounter more transitional cutscenes - none of which are skippable. I actually want to follow the story of a game so I'm cool with games requiring you to stick through cutscenes. Still I would strongly advocate to make every piece of a game that takes up time but doesn't provide game play to be skippable at the player's discretion. The game already got the player's money and shouldn't unnecessarily commandeer the player's time. I had times when the game actually felt like a boring chore.The controls are somewhat outdated. When running into a "steep" inclination you usually cannot jump. This is right away irritating because it takes away the functionality of one of the main buttons without apparent explanation. I guess, it's because you're supposed to slide on steep inclinations - a nicer device to limit levels than invisible walls (which are also in the game) - and at the bottom you're sort of halfway on the inclination. There are some places where you can slide into stuff in a way that makes it very hard to slide around them which is nevertheless the only option - except for quitting - since you cannot jump at the time.Stairs are usually a device to ease ascent, in this game they often fail to do so. You're often better off just jumping up stairs. In case they are winding you'll notice that the game is a bit lacking in providing a sense of depth. Although the camera is not too close to the ground most of the time, the camera often jumps between certain pretty fix position, then swivels. This in combination with upwards movement can lead to unfortunate angles.When playing in "free play" you can effectively choose two characters that enter a level and the game will provide a number of further characters in a way that all skills necessary to complete a level's secondary goals are available. You can then switch between those characters. I couldn't figure out how the game sorts the extras and so had to learn them for each level.You're always running around with at least two characters. That way you can play as one or two players. The extra character(s) can be quite a hassle. If there are fewer players than characters you can tag and change the currently played character. When you're running with more characters it can be hard to change to the wanted character. When attacking something extra characters are often in the way as the auto-aiming rather hits an extra than anything else. Sometimes extras are blocking you sometimes they keep their distance when you want to tag them. NPC cooperation, e.g. when having to pull two levers at roughly the same time, is still a bit lacking in this game.The problem with camera angles is even more problematic with ingame rewards, mainly LEGO studs that act as currency in the game and are also part of secondary level goals. Reward collection policy in LEGO games has always been an issue with me, right from the first time a stud vanished into an abyss. So what about the camera? The studs in this game do not have a shadow so their movement in 3D space is somewhat hard to follow. Sometimes you can translate from the movement of another stud moving on the screen plane, i.e. at a right angle to the player's line of sight. Why do you need to follow movement anyway? Most ingame rewards vanish after about 4 seconds which is relatively short. Most ingame rewards are not collectible right away, i.e. studs usually have approximately a second after they appear in which they are protected from collection. Some rewards drop down an abyss or jump behind a wall right away. If there wasn't the argument that there are basically always more studs to collect I'd find that unbearable - so I'm only somewhat upset. Also, game designers were aware of that as is evidenced by the fact that certain levels change policy so that every stud is automatically collected.My policy would have all studs collectible right away, no time-related vanishing, no jumping through walls and always dropping a shadow.The game has a few dead-ends, i.e. places you can get to but cannot get away from without quitting a level. There is also a bit of unnecessary tunneling. Example 1: In free play despite having a character that can theoretically make it across wide abysses the game still drops you into the abyss because it just wants you to take the scenic route. Example 2: Some silver object cannot be bombed unless some other object has been built despite the object to-be-build and the silver object never interacting.There are a few flying missions. Whenever you happen to collect a power-up - which due to bad visibility cannot always be avoided - the game starts to make an unnerving sound for the duration of the power-up. Later in my game I simply turned off sounds altogether.Again, I recommend LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga to those that don't mind playing only the main part of the game or have a high tolerance against boredom when 100%-ing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												"LEGO® Star Wars™ - The Complete Saga" is basically as the name implies, it's a Lego game that contains the saga of Star Wars, well until Episode VII just released haha.This game features a hub world where you first start and includes all 6 Episodes and within each Episode there are six Missions and one/two Bonus missions. Only Episode 1 is unlocked in the beginning, but if you complete the first mission you'll unlock all the other Episodes. So if you don't like the prequels just do the first mission and then skip the rest and jump straight into Episode 4. There is also a "Gold" bonus area that has extra content to do if you get all Gold blocks in the game.You're not going to find voice acting in this game unless it's the droid sounds, so there is little to none of the political scenes from the movies(at least so far in Episode 1). If you're looking for pretty much an all action version of Star Wars this is the game to get that experience. However there are some missing scenes from the movie that I would have liked to see in this game like the underwater ship in Episode 1 is skipped when that could have been part of a mission for more collectibles/blocks. There is also no space scene with Anakin when he's in the N-1 which I thought could have been a cool addition. The pod racing is included however. So very mixed so far in Episode 1 of what scenes you'd expect to see. Probably more missing scenes like this in the later Episodes.As for performance I'm getting 60fps 100% of the time in-game at 1920x1080, but when there's cutscenes I've noticed there are framedrops occuring but they come back to 60fps. So a bit stuttering when in cutscenes. Not sure what the cause is, but it isn't that big of a deal to me since I'm just watching and not playing.Controller support does feel perfect in the game, I don't have the time currently to find a local co-op partner and test two controllers plugged in, but I'm assuming it works fine. If it doesn't I'll update my review and make note of it.So far I'm very happy with the game. I used to play Lego games a long time ago on my original Xbox back when it was split into two parts and this Complete Saga on PC plays exactly how I remember it years ago. I'd say it's worth $19.99 if you know you're going to be playing this and wanting to collect everything and it's 100% a for sure purchase at $5.99 on sale even if you're just going to casually run through it.

Posted: January 10, 2016
												I originally had the Lego Star Wars the Video Game on my GameCube. It was part of my childhood. Unfortunately, I never bought the Original Saga of Lego Star Wars. This thing has them both, with a bunch of connecting details. Instead of two separate games in one bundle, they are truly combined into just one game. For example, you have to be a Stormtrooper to access areas in Episode I, II, and III. It's a joy to be able to purchase this beauty on Steam and play it with a controller. The ability to relive some of my childhood memories with a boost in the graphic quaility is amazing! I always played Lego Star Wars on older TVs, so it feels odd to see it with a 1080p resolution and higher framerate. If you want to play a Star Wars game that has a TON of content and replayability, this is certainly a viable option.There is nothing serious about it! It really is just a playground of Star Wars fun. XD

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												I took a trip back to my childhood with this game and I gotta say: playing through both LEGO Star Wars games in one collection is pretty neat. I still remember the novelty of battling across the stars with my friends as we discovered the secrets of Free Play mode in every level. Tt Games really nailed replayability in these games, encouraging players to return to previously inaccessible areas of a level by using unlockable heroes with their special abilities. One thing has to be said about the original LEGO Star Wars, though: it hasn't held up especially well. I found the sequel to be the much more enjoyable and memorable of the two thanks to its clever level design and quirky humor. The first game is noticably slower paced and lacks the visually gags that add so much to its sequel. Regardless, it was nice to take a trip down memory lane and remind myself what all successive LEGO franchise games built themselves upon.It's really hard to say no to a package that packs in so much content. Hundreds of iconic Star Wars characters and tons of replayability keep me coming back for more from the galaxy far, far, away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I have played Lego Games for a long time, mostly on consoles and stuff. Foudn this game on sale, bought it and boy did the memories flood back. One of the best Star Wars games out there.The characters move really well (Only had some problems with double jumping sometimes.) and can fight well too. Every character feels unique in some way, either their powers or some special animations. The levels are all well designed. Each level feels fun to play through, except for the vehicle levels. Some of the vehicle levels can be really fun to play through (Pod Racing being my favorite) while some are annoying due to the fact that you go straight across the screen when tapping a button. More often than not did i die because of the bad controls on these levels.Each level contains one powerbrick, 10 minikits, a bunch of studs to collect to purchase stuff back at the Cantina. More often than not will you have to return to a level to fully complete it, but since most levels are fun, it doesnt matter too much.Accessing levels, buying new characters, creating characters and more all takes place at the Mos Eisley Cantina. Its made so you can easily find your way to levels, extra levels, minigames and more.I recommend buying the game and playing through it. Its more fun with a friend though, since alot of the puzzles are based around two people.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I have played Lego Games for a long time, mostly on consoles and stuff. Foudn this game on sale, bought it and boy did the memories flood back. One of the best Star Wars games out there.The characters move really well (Only had some problems with double jumping sometimes.) and can fight well too. Every character feels unique in some way, either their powers or some special animations. The levels are all well designed. Each level feels fun to play through, except for the vehicle levels. Some of the vehicle levels can be really fun to play through (Pod Racing being my favorite) while some are annoying due to the fact that you go straight across the screen when tapping a button. More often than not did i die because of the bad controls on these levels.Each level contains one powerbrick, 10 minikits, a bunch of studs to collect to purchase stuff back at the Cantina. More often than not will you have to return to a level to fully complete it, but since most levels are fun, it doesnt matter too much.Accessing levels, buying new characters, creating characters and more all takes place at the Mos Eisley Cantina. Its made so you can easily find your way to levels, extra levels, minigames and more.I recommend buying the game and playing through it. Its more fun with a friend though, since alot of the puzzles are based around two people.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												These two games started the current Licensed "Travelers Tales formula" and they execute it the best (also you dont have to beat the game to access freemode, or listen to awful jokes by the characters Im looking at you Lego Batman 2)  Which one is better?Lego Starwars 2 has better humour, not just in cutscenes but the general enviroment is jam packed with outrageousness. The stages also feel more refined then Lego Starwars 1, there definitely aren't as many bs deaths either. Battle Mechanics and GameplaySadly this is the weakest aspect of the game, it has the simplicity of an early one button beat em up. Some characters are capable of doing more then just mashing the attack button, such as a rolling and then rapid fire or a force blast with a swipe. But for the most part the battling is weak, fights are usually short lived due to enemy HP being so fragile. If you're playing solo great ready to watch your AI partner never kill or assist you in a boss fight. They'll pretend they doing something (such as blocking or purposely shooting to the side of the enemy) but they're programmed to never kill... for whatever reason.SoundYou can hate this entire game all you want but the soundtrack is spectactular. It's straight out of the movies.ChoiceCharacter variety is huge and I'm not talking about just character models. I would say there are different groupings of characters and each group has something that sets it apart from each other (Droids, Sithlords, Bounty Hunters, Troopers, Jedi, Indiana Jones. Rebels, YOUR CUSTOM CHARACTER(S), Lulzy characters, Misceclanous characters).  Even in these groups almost every character is unqiue in some manner. Stage DesignFor those who have seen the series you will have no trouble recnogizing every piece of secenery, with a hint of Lego humour invovled. Bonus items are well placed and at times incredibly cryptic. The puzzles are basic at times and actually challenging at others (suprising if you've played other TT Lego games...).ReplabitlityYou will find yourself going back to a stage 2 or 3 times (especially for the Hoth Battle, Deathstar Run and Speeder Bike stages). Or you could play straight forward through the story and replay the free modes to 100%.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
Episode VII: The Bricks AwakenThis game was the childhood of most 20-something year-olds who played video games. And, really, what's not to love? Traveler's Tales had a well-built and finely constructed vision of a galaxy far, far away entirely made of LEGO bricks (well, not entirely). What's there to say that hasn't already been said?Now that we're all adults, it turns out, there's quite a bit more to discuss about this. The episodes focusing on the Prequel Trilogy have had slight adjustments to account for the improvements made in Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy. Minikits are now playable in some sections, and powerups drop, enabling increased stud pickup radius, invicibility, and increased stud value. I personally prefer the Prequel Trilogy sections of the game, but the entire experience is phenomenal in a familiar way.The game is definitely rough, visually, but seeing famous Star Wars characters and locations in LEGO form is still a treat. Music from the series is used to great effect, and the sound effects are spot-on. Canned character animations can get old, but you'll hardly care since you're controlling DARTH MAUL IN LEGO FORM. Most relevant sections from the movies have been included in some form, and the silent, physical humor is still hilarious.Having to complete each level in one sitting is a little bit of a pain, but the levels are short enough that this usually isn't an issue. In Free Play, unlimited access to characters removes this problem as you create shortcuts or decimate enemies in ways the level never intended.Red Bricks, which grant bonuses at the cost of studs, are gradually unlocked. Some are amusing, some are useful (magnetically drawing in studs is a godsend), and some break the game (the higher levels of the stud combo multipliers, invicibility, perfect deflection), but all are welcome.The character roster is huge, and while a few too many spots are devoted to joke characters or clones (no pun intended), it's still a welcome sight to see the number of available characters increase. The manner in which certain areas are locked off to certain characters is never frustrating due to how they steadily allow you to unlock the characters you need to revisit previous levels and get everything that can be found.The episodes are all consistently good, though some of the vehicle sections and camera angles don't quite hold up when it comes to quality.Gold Bricks can be used to unlcok several bonus levels, and while some are entertaining, most you'll only complete to get the Gold Brick needed to get closer to 100% and then never look back. Lego city and its counterpart are particularly frustrating.The only other unwelcome aspect is the Super Story: while fun in theory (speedrunning through each movie using only the characters accesible when you first played the level), the fact that its needed to acquire 100% is a bit of a tough pill to swallow considering that Super Story adds nothing new. I have ~99% completion, but the thought of replaying levels I've already finished without being able to swap characters turned me off from that final completion point.Overall, though, this game is as fantastic as you remember. If you haven't played it, there's a huge amount of content here, most of it excellent. If you have, give it another go. You won't regret it.ProsHuge, varied character rosterExcellent music, of courseLEGO versions of characters, vehicles and places are nice to seeMost levels are perfectly paced and great funHuge amount of great contentConsCamera angles are sometimes iffySome vehicle sections drag on for a bit too long or aren't quite as good as you rememberVisually dated in comparison to Lego Star Wars III: The Clone WarsSome bonus levels are repetitive or frustratingLarge number of joke characters

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 8
												If you've played any other of the Lego games, you've played this one. They're all very much alike. If you haven't played a Lego game before, they're 3d puzzle-based action games, in the vein of Mario 64. They're very easy to play with simple controls.I enjoy playing Star Wars Lego with my easily excited four year old, who loves it and is always asking to play. It's gentle enough for him to enjoy it. The production values and polish are great, and it's STAR WARS. It has lots of in-jokes and nods to the source materials. There are lots of collectables which give some replayability - I couldn't be bothered myself.As of about five years ago, all six existing Star Wars films were catered for (i.e. the original trilogy and prequels), hence the title. It doesn't include anything from the more recent films, those are in different games. Each film has about six levels (so 36 in total). If you haven't seen the films then the plot is likely incomprehensible. Who hasn't seen Star Wars though?

content:
Posted: January 15
												A simple but fun game, going for 100% completion was a bit of a grind due to the repetition (playing through the entire story multiple times to find all minikits, power bricks, etc). Getting 100% took just shy of 50 hours, so you get quite a bit of game without adding the replay value. That being said, I played both games as a kid before the complete saga was even released, lots of fun gameplay here still, and of course I always recommend getting games on sale, but I'd still pay full price for this game. 8.5/10 would grind my life away again.

content:
Posted: February 26
												When I saw that this game was on sale over Christmas I freaked out. I remember playing this as a kid and loving it, and it brought back so many memories! Many people say that the controls were hard to get used to, but after a few minutes, I got into the swing of things. The levels are all different, and challenging often, but some of the space levels, especially "falcon flight" and the first part of the destruction of the second Death Star are boring and monotonous. Some of the levels and enemies can be a bit infuriating, but there is always something to do, and returning to the levels for free play and challenge modes is totally worth it. Very fun game, 100% worth it to complete the entire thing, very rewarding as I never finished the entire thing as a kid.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												This is LEGO's first video game adaptation of a film series, and it's definitely not without serious aging. The first con I couldn't get around was the game's restrictive bug that keeps the game at 4:3 ratio at a standard defition resolution. If you try setting it to widescreen or at a higher resolution (which the video settings menu says you can do), the game freezes up completely, leaving you no choice but to restart. My computer was built for high-functioning games in 2015, yet not even that can bring this game up to modern display standards! There are also frame rate issues at certain points mid-game that make you think your computer's a dinosaur.On the other hand, you have the promising fun of the Star Wars saga combined with the ingenuity and creativity of LEGO. If you want to free Princess Leia as Dex, go ahead. If you want the satisfaction of killing Jar Jar over and over again as Darth Vader, that's your choice! When it comes to thrills and speed however, you may get frustrated with having to run half as fast as you know the character should. No force-boosts there. But the controls all work, the gagetry is fun, and the reimagined scenes from the movies have their fair share of added humor and wit. Just, good luck with your patience.
